title: ESPnet-SpeechLM: An Open Speech Language Model Toolkit
author: Jinchuan Tian (Carnegie Mellon University), Jiatong Shi (Carnegie Mellon University), William Chen (Carnegie Mellon University), Siddhant Arora (Carnegie Mellon University), Yoshiki Masuyama (Mitsubishi Electric Research Laboratories), Takashi Maekaku (LY Corporation), Yihan Wu (Renmin University of China), Junyi Peng (Brno University of Technology), ..., Shinji Watanabe (Carnegie Mellon University)
relevance_why: The toolkit focuses on speech language models, which align closely with Haohe Liu's research interests in audio and speech processing, especially in text-to-audio generation and audio quality enhancement.
background: The paper introduces a toolkit for developing speech language models that supports various tasks such as automatic speech recognition and text-to-speech synthesis.
contribution: ESPnet-SpeechLM introduces a standardized workflow and modular framework for the efficient development of Speech Language Models (SpeechLMs) to solve challenges in speech processing, achieving competitive results on several benchmarks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in SpeechLM development were complex and resource-heavy, often lacking transparency in processes.
technical_comparison.novelty: This toolkit simplifies the SpeechLM development process through a unified workflow that includes data preprocessing, training, inference, and evaluation, making it accessible and reproducible.

key_innovation: The modular design allows users to configure various components easily, including task definitions, model architectures, and tokenization methods, facilitating versatile SpeechLM applications.
real_world_impact: By democratizing SpeechLM development, the toolkit could enable more robust and diverse applications in voice-driven technologies, such as conversational agents and assistive technologies.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Speech Language Models: **Speech Language Models (SpeechLMs)** are models designed to process and generate spoken language, integrating speech and text understanding capabilities.
new_terms.tokenization: **Tokenization** is the process of converting raw data into a format suitable for modeling, often by breaking it down into smaller components or tokens.

open_sourcing: The toolkit is fully open-source and available at: https://github.com/espnet/espnet/tree/speechlm.
